Award.AwardTitle: Collab. Research: Instability analysis of the split-step method on spatially-varying backgrounds, with applications to optical telecommunications and Bose-Einstein condensation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The operator-splitting, or split-step, method (SSM) is widely used to numerically solve time-dependent partial differential equations arising in diverse applications, from hydrodynamics to quantum mechanics. To minimize the computational time, one needs to select the time step as large as possible. On the other hand, the upper bound on the time step is often set by the requirement that the numerical scheme be stable. The von Neumann analysis is used to obtain such upper bounds for model problems where the coefficients are constant. However, solutions of practically interesting equations are typically not constant in space. To justify the use of the von Neumann analysis for such problems, one often approximates non-constant coefficients by constant ones. However, for the SSM, this approach fails. Recently, the PIs proposed an alternative approach to analyze the instability of the SSM when this method is used to simulate a solution close to the soliton (i.e., a bell-shaped solution) of the nonlinear Schroedinger equation. In this project, the PIs will extend that analysis to more practically relevant settings that involve two applications: fiber optical telecommunications and Bose-Einstein condensates. This will provide an understanding of the development of the numerical instability in problems with essentially non-constant coefficients. They will then use this information to propose modifications of the SSM with relaxed stability requirements. Clearly, this will reduce the computational time.

This project will develop a systematic approach to studying a fundamental property - stability - of a widely used numerical method, the SSM. A numerical method must be stable in order to accurately model the physical process of interest. The current approach to the stability analysis consists in approximating the simulated processes by some constant values. The PIs will not use this approximation, as they have demonstrated that it leads to incorrect predictions regarding the performance of the SSM. Their alternative approach will rely on a combination of techniques from numerical analysis and the theory of linear differential equations. It will provide an understanding of the performance limitations of the SSM. This, in turn, will allow them to propose more efficient and reliable modifications of this numerical method. The applications considered in this project will directly impact the modeling of fiber-optic communication systems and low-temperature atomic condensates. However, their approach will affect other applications of the SSM, which include environmental modeling, hydrology, heat conduction, and reacting flows. Moreover, the approach can be extended to related numerical methods, which are used in other applications such as the modeling of the interaction among molecules and chemical species through reactions and random motion (diffusion).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The split-step (also known as operator-splitting or fractional step) method is widely used to numerically solve time-dependent partial differential equations arising in diverse applications, from hydrodynamics to quantum mechanics. It is explicit and easy to implement, however, the split-step method suffers numerical instability. In practice, one has to select the time step, on one hand, to guarantee stability and sufficient accuracy, on the other hand, to minimize the computational time for efficient massive simulations.

This research project investigates the numerical instability of the split-step method in solving the nonlinear Schrodinger (NLS) equations, also known as the Gross-Pitaevskii equation (GPE) in the community of Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC). Our research objectives are to understand the fundamental mechanics of the split-step method, to control and suppress its numerical instability, and to propose more efficient and reliable modifications of this numerical method.

We developed new and improved split-step methods to solve the Gross-Pitaevskii equation under different boundary conditions and applied them to study the dynamic behavior of Bose-Einstein condensation. The numerical instability of the split-step method presented in solving Gross-Pitaevskii equation is very irregular, especially in the presence of an external potential. We systematically studied how numerical instability of the split-step method develops. The instability threshold of the time step is obtained for avoiding the numerical instability. Additionally, we investigated the radiation of waves and boundary reflections under both periodic and homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions and found that absorbing boundary conditions can suppress numerical instability effectively. This approach allows one to use time steps that exceed the instability threshold by a factor of two or three.

Our results benefit the research in the areas of both fiber optical telecommunications and Bose-Einstein condensation.  The new and improved numerical methods that we developed for solved the Gross-Pitaevskii equation will greatly benefit the research in the area of Bose-Einstein condensation. Some of them have been collected in computer software packages for simulating BEC. This research provided a deeper understanding of the numerically stability of the split-step, as well as the knowledge of which Fourier modes cause the numerical instability. The analysis that we developed provides an additional tool in the collection of methods of numerical analysis and can be applied beyond the scope of the split-step method. Moreover, our analysis could be applied to numerical schemes other than the split-step method. The threshold of time step we found provides a guideline for choosing the time step, so as to avoid numerical instability in simulations. It will benefit the massive simulations in the areas, e.g., optical telecommunications and Bose-Einstein condensation, where simulations play a significant role in understanding their phenomena. Additionally, our numerical results of the stationary states of the nonlocal Schrodinger equation in an infinite potential well provide insights to one fundamental question in the fractional quantum mechanics. This is the first numerical study reported in the literature on this problem.

The applications considered in this project will directly impact the modeling of fiber-optic communication systems and low-temperature atomic condensates. Their approach will affect other applications of the split-step method, which include environmental modeling, hydrology, heat conduction, and reacting flows. Moreover, the approach can be extended to related numerical methods, which are used in other applications such as the modeling of the interaction among molecules and chemical species through reactions and random motion (diffusion). This award supported one PhD student, the first student of the new computational and applied mathematics program at the department of mathematic and statistics, Missouri University of Science and Technology. The support from NSF has enhanced the new PhD program and encouraged more students to pursue their degree in computational and applied mathematics. Additionally, the workstation supported by this award benefits all students and faculty members at the department of mathematics and statistics.

This research project results in ten journal papers (five published in refereed journals, two manuscripts under review, and another three to be submitted shortly).  The results of this project have been presented in eleven conference presentations and one poster presentation. This project supports the training of one PhD student in the computational and applied mathematics, a new program at the Department of Mathematics and Statistics, Missouri University of Science and Technology. During this project, the PhD student has completed the majority of her PhD dissertation.
